reviewText: I've been playing with the XBox 360 controller and this game feels like a really solid port.  It performs well, has smooth controls, and I haven't encountered any bugs so far.  The game itself is a fun platformer with collectibles and puzzle-solving.  If you are playing by yourself, the AI for Oswald is good enough to get by no problem.  Lots of charming Disney songs, animations, and artwork!\n\nEDIT:  I beat the game today and I was able to finish the game without encountering any bugs other than Winslow getting stuck sometimes.  Overall a very fun platformer!
voteText: 75 of 111 people (68%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I don't see where people are coming from complaining about technical issues in this game. Multi-core, specific resolutions and such.  And with less than an hour of runnng the game to say the least.
It runs just fine for me in 1080p on a 6-core processor.

For the simple platformer that it is,  I enjoy it. Someone mentioned Spyro as a comparison, and though it's not nearly as focused a game, I tend to agree.  It's got that classic Disney cartoon vibe to it which helps give it a warm feel.

If you go into it not expecting it to break new ground genre wise or simply not to be complete trash (your mind already being set), you're sure to enjoy it.

reviewText:
A somewhat dated MickeyRating: Ok

The graphics feel a bit dated and the controls (X360) isn't the best but so far having fun running around as Mickey. The game is really meant to play as co-op, and when playing alone Oswald will do the stuff he is suppose to do himself. Would have been nicer if you actually could switch positions.

reviewText:
My recommendation may change, but for now I'm going to recommend people pass. I personally can't get it running on my system (freezes at startup). I've tried about every tweak/fix I can think of.

*Update2* Okay, Gorilla has a possible fix. It involves limiting the number of cores used in Windows. Hardly ideal since may hurt performance in other games/tasks, but at least it gets the game running for me.

There are also some other issues. Apparently the game:
a) has no local co-op
b) has a 30fps lock
c) may not have trading cards, despite what the store page says

If you are interested in the game I'd suggest putting it on your Wishlist and checking back in a week or so. See how things work out for people who bought it, whether it gets patched, and whether we come up with fixes for the framerate/coop issues. As it is stands, you're better off hanging onto your money until we see if this can get sorted out.

(edit: added forum links) (edit2: added trading card info) (edit3: cpu issue info) (edit4: cpu fix info)

reviewText:
As other reviews mention, game breaking bugs can cause frequent crashes, freezing, and even make progression impossible. You might be fortunate enough to be able to actually finish the game, but be sure to test it first. If you have any crashes in the first hour or two you should expect the rest of the game to play that way (and potentially reach a point where you can't progress); if not, you're probably in the clear, but it's not a guarantee.

The most common offender is cutscenes, particularly the transition from the Underground to Mean Street North. Some are never able to move past that point, others can reload the game and move on. I was able to get through it, but whenever I attempted to use the camera item I immediately crashed to the desktop (even just staring at the ground, so it's not a weird issue with draw distance or loading lots of art and textures), and have since given up further attempts to make the game work.

The community hub is filled with similar reports, and these issues have never been resolved by the developer. There is a thread reporting some success by  limiting the number of cores in use  just to make the game work correctly, to give you an idea of what a poor port this is. On top of these problems, the controls feel clunky and this version of the game removed co-op, leaving you to deal with the occasionally frustrating and clumsy AI controlling Gus.

If you're able to look past the bugs and serious functionality issues, and not run into any sections that block progression, the game itself is an average platformer with lots of collectibles, but nothing particularly special. If you really want to play it you should stick to the console versions.

reviewText:
1) Essential purchase
2) Recommended purchase
3) Recommended purchase during a sale
4) Not recommended unless heavily discounted
5) Not even recommended for Steam game collectors
If you know me personally or follow my curator group you will know that I try my hardest to write detailed, thorough and hopefully helpful reviews for the games that I play here on Steam. I also have a rule that I only review games that I have fully completed.  In the end whether those reviews end up being positive or negative; I always strive to be fair and honest but this is one game I am breaking that rule for (not for the lack of trying to complete the dam thing), a game that deserves no more of my precious time (let alone me sitting here typing up a detailed non-recommendation) so this review will be very brief because quite frankly it deserves nothing more.

I will not be listing any merits (since I couldn't find any - especially for those of us who choose the PC as their desired platform of choice) nor will I be mentioning any cons (just know that this entire game is a complete con on PC) for Epic Mickey 2: The Power of Two. I will not dedicate any more time than is necessary seeing as though I have already wasted 17 hrs of my life trying to see this worthless and broken piece of donkey dung to an end and in the end the game wouldn't even allow me that. Considering the hoops I had to jump through just to get there, it was a bitter pill to swallow.

So...no dear reader if you came here expecting a detailed and thorough review, I am terribly sorry to disappoint. You are probably better off looking elsewhere.  If Epic Mickey 2: The Power of Two was a person it could rot in its own faeces for all I care. Disney go home - and take your crap with you! As for Warren Spector and Junction Point - F*&K YOU and the little mouse you rode in on!

If you enjoyed reading this review please follow my curator group at:-
Curator Rater

reviewText:
Sadly I can't recommend this game to anyone. I haven't had the chance to play the first game, but I heard good things about it and I was really hoping that Epic Mickey 2 will be a great 3D platformer, but it's far from it, especially on PC.

The first thing I noticed that the game feels clunky. It often feels like a game from the era when developers were still just experimenting with the idea of 3D in a platformer and often times those games just doesn't feel right. It's something like that here, quite often I couldn't tell wheter an item is behind me or in front of me and if so how far. It's hard to explain, but the 3D just doesn't feel right compared to other games. There are 2D levels as well, but those are mostly really short (and I DO mean really short, 1-3 minutes mostly...).

That's the least of my worries though with this game, there are much bigger ones as well sadly. The PC port is just bad. Both optimization/graphics and control-wise. Especially the latter, the controls are terrible with keyboard+mouse. I pretty much always prefer to play my games with kb+m, but I'd really recommend using a gamepad if you really want to play this game (which you shouldn't).

...and lastly what really killed the game for me that it's basically a coop game that you can play alone as well and it just doesn't work well in solo. The AI is the worst I've seen since the late '90s. Oswald never does what you want him to do, never around when you need him and pretty much just runs around aimlessly while you wait for him so you can proceed with the game. I wouldn't even bother playing this alone to be honest, the AI pretty much killed all the fun.

All in all Epic Mickey 2 is the shoddy port of a mediocre game with terrible AI. It might be fun if you can get someone to play this with you (using controllers), otherwise skip this one, there are better platformers out there.

reviewText:
First of all I haven't played the first game, so there won't be any comparison of both games. Well maybe a slight.

I looooooooved the concept this game brought out. The classics and the paintbrush made me so giddy! Nice work on combining the classic looks and 3D appeal. The game mechanics is very easy to learn and understand. Of course this is a kids game, so I certainly hope so!  I just love the sense of nostalgia it brings out.

However, my strongest agitation from this game is the extreme hand holding. The moment Gus and Oswald joins Mickey, Gus will constantly almost every 5 seconds repeat the same hints. One of the simple beginning puzzle of getting out of the crumbling castly is paint a toon. I painted everything! Including the two npcs! I painted especially painted a figure that looked like a toon that needed a head. Figured Mickey was supposed to paint it back to life. Nope! It was Gus. The one toon that kept saying, THERE HAS TO BE A TOON YOU CAN PAINT". ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. He was the first I attacked too since he is so obnoxious. Oswald was fun

reviewText:
This is a game that was ment for consoles, and it really shows with many things.  Such as the keyboard controls. These controls are some of the most awful controls I've seen in a video game yet. That's why you should NOT pick up this game unless you have a Xbox 360/PS3 controller. Also, to just nitpick here, you can't go into full screen, which is very annoying on PC games. Now besides the port problems, this game has some extremely annoying characters such as Gus, the little green thing that wont ever shut up. He is constantly holding your hand through every little part of the game that may require you to think, which not only makes him an annoying character, but he also near ruins the game. That's another thing about this game: There is no challenge what so ever. The boss battles are the only thing that could be considered semi-challenging, and there are about 3 in the entire game, meaning the majority of the game is easy. Also, the game feels like DLC for Epic Mickey 1 more than anything, since it is so short. Really, you could probably beat the game in LESS THAN AN HOUR. Imagine purchasing a broken $60 game that only lasts 40 minutes. I'd be pretty ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off. Other complaints I had where the voice acting. Now I suppose you could probably deal with it, but really, the acting is pretty bad in this game. As well as the musical segments. Yep, musical segments. This game was marketed as a musical game, but really there are about 5 ♥♥♥♥♥♥ songs in the entire game that are all sung by the same character. I wouldn't qualify this a musical. Now there are a few things I liked about the game. One of them being the boss battles. The battles brought in a change to the game, allowing you to choose how you defeat them: Turning them into a friendly,  or killing them. I though this was a great idea in Epic Mickey 1 and it is still a great idea in Epic Mickey 2. However, other games have done this practice MUCH better than Epic Mickey, because in this game, your choices don't really matter. If you pick the good choice, you are praised as a hero in the end. If you pick the bad choice, you are praised as a hero in the end. Though that doesn't really take away from the over all enjoyment of the fight. Another thing I liked was the enviroment. If you didn't know, the world is pretty much a destroyed Disneyland, however, the first game did this much better. On consoles this was an over all decent game, on PC however, it is a bad game. So if you want to play one of these games, GET THE THE FIRST ONE, or purchase this game on consoles. I still do recommend getting the first one, because it is a pretty good game, and it will help you understand this one better.

Consoles: 3/5
PC: 2/5

Not recommended unless you are a fan of the original game, or if you are interested in Disney history.

reviewText:
This is a great game. Granted it's not as good as the first Epic Mickey game, but it's still pretty good. Sadly though, there is no 2player mode so it might take a while to beat with CPU Oswald. But the game is also kinda short if you know what you're doing and the story isn't as good as the story in the first game. But at least there's voice acting! :D The only downside to the voice acting is that the Mad Doctor's lines are songs and he's constantly singing.
I give this game a 7.8/10
Not as good as the first Epic Mickey, but still good and is definitely worth a play. Especially if you're a hardcore Disney fan.
But I suggest playing the first game before playing Power of Two that way you understand the story of the second game and that way you also know who the heck Ortensia is and how Mickey already knows all these characters.
But yeah it's a great game and I recommend it.

reviewText:
Not that bad of a game.  It certainly looks better than it's predecessor. Heck it even has voice acting now which is neat.
I really didn't expect the paint reticule to work as well as it did since it was meant or mouse or wii-mote but it worked great with an xbox controller.
Some of my favorite scenes happened when the mad doctor showed up and turned whatever scene he was in into a musical because he refused to speak in anything other than song.

There is a whole lot of content in this game.  So much so that I kept feeling like I was missing stuff as I progressed through each level, such as different paths I could have taken to see where they lead or quests I just couldn't complete because I may have screwed something up in another part of the area.

For the most part I tried to stick with the hero path but I inadertantly caused more damage in a lot of areas than I meant to because I thought I was doing the right thing or defending myself.

Anyhoo it was an enjoyable experience and perhaps I'll give it another go eventually to find all the secrets that I might have passed by.
